qas.question: What type of role that Islamism seeks makes it a somewhat controversial concept?
What do supporters of Islamism believe their views reflect?
The idea that Islam can be apolitical isn't able to be embraced by whom?
What does the inability to separate Islam from Islamism lead many in the West to support?
What do progressive moderates of Islam seek to separate?
What type of role that Islamism seeks makes it not a controversial concept?
What don't supporters of Islamism believe their views reflect?
The idea that Islam can't be apolitical isn't able to be embraced by whom?
What does the inability to separate Islam from Islamism lead many in the Eest to support?
What don't progressive moderates of Islam seek to separate?

context: <a2_2>Islamism<a2_2/> is a controversial concept not just because it posits a <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>political<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> role for <b6_0>Islam<b6_0/> but also because <a2_0>its <b7_0>supporters<b7_0/><a2_0/> believe their views merely reflect <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Islam<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, while the contrary idea that Islam is, or can be, apolitical is an error. <a2_1>Scholars and observers<a2_1/> who do not believe that Islam is merely a political ideology include Fred Halliday, John Esposito and Muslim intellectuals like Javed Ahmad Ghamidi. Hayri Abaza argues the failure to distinguish between Islam and Islamism leads many in the West to support <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>illiberal Islamic regimes<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, to the detriment of progressive moderates who seek to separate <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>religion from politics<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
